content: The "Civil Rights Act of 1997" is the short title of this Act, which aims to address findings and purposes related to civil rights. The "Civil Rights Act of 1997" aims to provide equal protection of the laws and prohibit discrimination in the Federal Government based on race, color, national origin, or sex. Congress finds that the Constitution guarantees equal protection regardless of these factors, and the Supreme Court has affirmed this in recent rulings. The Federal Government currently has over 150 programs that grant preferences based on these criteria. The "Civil Rights Act of 1997" prohibits discrimination in the Federal Government based on race, color, national origin, or sex. The "Civil Rights Act of 1997" prohibits discrimination in the Federal Government based on race, color, national origin, or sex. Additionally, Section 3 of the Act prohibits discrimination and preferential treatment. The "Civil Rights Act of 1997" prohibits intentional discrimination or preferential treatment based on race, color, national origin, or sex in Federal contracts, employment, and programs. It also prohibits requiring or encouraging discrimination by Federal contractors or recipients of licenses or financial assistance. The "Civil Rights Act of 1997" prohibits discrimination based on race, color, national origin, or sex in Federal contracts, employment, and programs. Affirmative action is permitted. The Act allows the Federal Government to encourage women and minority-owned businesses to bid for contracts and recruit qualified individuals without granting preferences based on race, color, national origin, or sex. It also permits the government to require or encourage Federal contractors to promote diversity. It also permits the government to require or encourage Federal contractors to promote diversity by recruiting women and minorities for employment or encouraging their businesses to bid for contracts. SEC. 5. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not restrict actions benefiting historically Black colleges or universities, Indian tribes under specific laws or treaties, or sex-based classifications in employment exempt from Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Act does not affect immigration or nationality laws. SEC. 6. Compliance review of policies and regulations requires each department or agency head to review and modify existing policies to comply with the Act within 1 year. They must report any changes to the Judiciary Committees. SEC. 7. Remedies are also outlined in the Act. SEC. 7. REMEDIES. Any person aggrieved by a violation of section 3 may obtain relief in a civil action, including back pay. A prevailing plaintiff shall be awarded attorney's fees. This section does not affect other available remedies. SEC. 8. EFFECT ON PENDING MATTERS. This Act does not impact pending cases or contracts/subcontracts in effect before enactment. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include the Federal Government as the executive and legislative branches of the United States, preference as any advantage like quotas or goals, and historically Black colleges as part B institutions under the Higher Education Act of 1965.
